pr_title: Adding test data sources designed for benchmarking purposes

timeline.message: add methods for distributed batch and stream stages w/ long values for high-throughput testing purposes
advanced source creation for performance testing

timeline.bodyText: Javadoc must be wrapped so that line length is 72 chars (ignoring initial indentation or *)
timeline.author: mtopolnik
mtopolnik

timeline.bodyText: Test method names shouldn't use _ arbitrarily. We use the camelCase except for the special format: when_preCondition_then_postCondition. The latter naming scheme is preferable for test methods.
timeline.author: mtopolnik

timeline.bodyText: You can reorder these two calls so that emitEvents() is first, then detectAndReportHiccup(). It is a bit cleaner that way.
timeline.author: mtopolnik

timeline.message: incorporated PR feedback (formatting, function call reordering), renamed method to stay consistent

timeline.bodyText: could these methods be moved to the top? we shouldn't have interleaving methods/inner classes
timeline.author: cangencer
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -161,4 +187,59 @@ void fillBuffer(TimestampedSourceBuffer<T> buf) throws Exception {
             }
         }
     }
+
+    /**
+     * Returns a {@link com.hazelcast.jet.pipeline.StreamSource} for {@code
+     * long} values. The value creation is distributed across the cluster and
+     * is done using {@link StreamSourceLong}. All {@link StreamSourceLong}
+     * instances are created identically, one per cluster member. The returned
+     * source is designed to be used for high-throughput performance testing.
+     *
+     * @param itemsPerSecond how many items should be emitted each second
+     * @param initialDelay initial delay before emitting values
+     *
+     * @return {@link com.hazelcast.jet.pipeline.StreamSource} with {@code long} values
+     *          created in a distributed fashion
+     *
+     * @since 4.3
+     *
+     */

+    public static StreamSource<Long> streamSourceLong(long itemsPerSecond, long initialDelay) {

timeline.bodyText: what unit is this in? is it in real-time or event time?
timeline.author: cangencer

replies.bodyText:
Unit is added in d476f97.
It is real-time, however, it only affects the earliest timestamp that is going to be emitted.
replies.author: guenter-hesse

timeline.bodyText: preferredLocalParallelism  can be already set at source stage level. What does it bring here?
timeline.author: cangencer

replies.bodyText:
As far as I can see, you can set the localParallelism at the stage level. Both, localParallelism and preferredLocalParallelism are considered in Vertex.determineLocalParallelism(int defaultParallelism):
/**
* Determines the local parallelism value for the vertex by looking
* its local parallelism and meta supplier's preferred local parallelism.
* If none of them is set, returns the provided default parallelism
*/
Does that answer your question?
replies.author: guenter-hesse

replies.bodyText: I guess we could remove preferredLocalParallelism from here, we have this feature for custom source implementations that can declare their preferred parallelism. But, since this is for ephemeral sources, we don't need it and can use sourceStage.setLocalParallelism()
replies.author: mtopolnik

timeline.bodyText: javadoc lacks detail about what timestamps the items will have

timeline.bodyText: why not .collect(toList()) directly?
timeline.author: cangencer

timeline.bodyText: I don't think you need the fully qualified name here, package is already imported.
timeline.author: cangencer

timeline.bodyText: in pipeline code, we always have . in the beginning of the line rather than end of previous.

timeline.bodyText: I would just inline this constant.

replies.bodyText: See other comment by @mtopolnik: "This and the one above were used as configurable parameters when this code was local. I'd leave them as constants now and potentially expose them for configuration later on."
replies.author: guenter-hesse

timeline.bodyText: Why don't we use nanos here too? We wouldn't have to convert below.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: This and the one above were used as configurable parameters when this code was local. I'd leave them as constants now and potentially expose them for configuration later on.

timeline.bodyText: The processor name should match the method name.
timeline.author: viliam-durina
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -132,6 +136,50 @@ private TestSources() { .build(); } + /** + * Returns a {@link StreamSource} that emits an ever-increasing sequence of + * {@code Long} numbers with native timestamps that are exactly the same + * amount of time apart, as specified by the supplied {@code + * eventsPerSecond} parameter. The source is distributed and suitable for + * high-throughput performance testing. It emits the events at the maximum + * possible speed, constrained by the invariant that it will never emit an + * event whose timestamp is in the future. + *

+ * The emission of events is distributed across the parallel processors in + * a round-robin fashion: processor 0 emits the first event, processor 1 + * the second one, and so on. There is no coordination that would prevent + * processor 1 from emitting its event before processor 0, though, so this + * only applies to the event timestamps. + *

+ * Use the {@code initialDelayMillis} parameter to give enough time to the + * Jet cluster to initialize the job on the whole cluster before the time + * of the first event arrives, so that there is no initial flood of events + * from the past. The point of reference is the moment at which the + * coordinator node creates the job's execution plan, before sending it out + * to the rest of the cluster. + *

+ * This source is not fault-tolerant. The sequence will be reset once a job + * is restarted. + * + * @param eventsPerSecond the desired event rate + * @param initialDelayMillis initial delay in milliseconds before emitting values + * + * @since 4.3 + * + */ + @Nonnull + public static StreamSource longStream(long eventsPerSecond, long initialDelayMillis) { + return Sources.streamFromProcessorWithWatermarks("longValues",

timeline.bodyText: We ignore the timestampFn in the eventTimePolicy. We also ignore the wrapFn: the pipeline will throw errors if one uses withoutTimestamp: it throws division by 0 because wmGranularity is 0 in that case.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

timeline.bodyText: minor: We get a different startTime for each member. Not sure we need to fix it, the members can still have drifted clocks, but maybe comment about it here...
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: The intention was to give the same startTime for all members, it should be rewritten to ensure it.
replies.author: mtopolnik

timeline.bodyText: We should use withNativeTimestamps(0) because that's what gets assigned to the items.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

timeline.bodyText: We should get the logger in init from context.getLogger()
timeline.author: viliam-durina

timeline.bodyText: We can initialize the coutner with globalProcessorIndex and add totalParallelism in each iteration. This way we'll avoid the calculation each time.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: This would break the invariant we rely on elsewhere, for the counter value to match the number of emitted events. The overhead of calculation isn't a concern, I think.
replies.author: mtopolnik

timeline.bodyText: Minor: We are not precise if there's a remainder. Instead of emitPeriod and emitSchedule we can calculate the expected counter value at current time and emit until it's greater than the current value. See for example here.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

timeline.bodyText:
We need to document:

that the emitted value is the timestamp value
that one has to use withNativeTimestamps(0) because other options are ignored (unless we fix it)
that members should have clocks synchronized
timeline.author: viliam-durina
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -132,6 +136,50 @@ private TestSources() { .build(); } + /** + * Returns a {@link StreamSource} that emits an ever-increasing sequence of + * {@code Long} numbers with native timestamps that are exactly the same + * amount of time apart, as specified by the supplied {@code + * eventsPerSecond} parameter. The source is distributed and suitable for + * high-throughput performance testing. It emits the events at the maximum + * possible speed, constrained by the invariant that it will never emit an + * event whose timestamp is in the future. + *

+ * The emission of events is distributed across the parallel processors in + * a round-robin fashion: processor 0 emits the first event, processor 1 + * the second one, and so on. There is no coordination that would prevent + * processor 1 from emitting its event before processor 0, though, so this + * only applies to the event timestamps. + *

+ * Use the {@code initialDelayMillis} parameter to give enough time to the + * Jet cluster to initialize the job on the whole cluster before the time + * of the first event arrives, so that there is no initial flood of events + * from the past. The point of reference is the moment at which the + * coordinator node creates the job's execution plan, before sending it out + * to the rest of the cluster. + *

+ * This source is not fault-tolerant. The sequence will be reset once a job + * is restarted.

replies.bodyText: The actual behavior is that the emitted value is a sequence 0,1,2,... About synchronized clocks: they should always be synchronized for member of a cluster so this doesn't create a new requirement. However, this can have a NOTE telling that the clock skew between any two members may result in an artificial increase of latency.
replies.author: mtopolnik

replies.bodyText: Corresponding extension of Javadoc done w/ 680f042
replies.author: guenter-hesse

timeline.message: Use the same startTime for all members

Expose private method in EventTimeMapper

Allow it to accept nanoTime() from the caller

Expose private method in EventTimeMapper

Allow it to accept nanoTime() from the caller
Change unit of hiccup threshold from ms to ns in order to reduce required unit conversions
Retrieve logger from Context in init method
Added note to Javadoc mentioning the consequences of a clock skew
Use native timestamps instead of ingestion ts in test
